(Narrative 1) What rationale is driving adaptation funding among different conceptions of vulnerability and classic and new development imperatives

Writer: Nicolas.

Until the early 2000s adaptation was disregarded as it was largely seen as a diversion from the ultimate objective of reducing greenhouse gas emissions (Godard, 2010). However, because of multiple factors (including growing doubts about the efficacy of mitigation engagements and increasing evidence on the unavoidability of impacts presented in the 2001 IPPC’s AR3) adaptation has since risen to the top of the international policy, research and expertise agendas, parallel to mitigation. This is the “adaptation turn” in UNFCCC negotiations, IPPC expertise, and national climate strategies.

At the international level of negotiations, adaptation became one of the four “pillars” of the Bali Action Plan in the 2007 Conference of the Parties (COP). In the expertise realm, The IPPC AR4 (2007) and, even more, the recent AR5 (2013-2014) have placed a renewed attention on adaptation. In sum, adaptation is now being integrated at all levels of climate politics – not just in international negotiations and expertise but also at the individual country level, from national to sub-national to municipal jurisdictions, in both developing and developed countries.

Adaptation to climate change suggests we need to transform how we think about and undertake development and spatial planning both at the global level (e.g. funding) and at the local level (e.g. design and implementation) in the face of expected impacts. However, the question rises: the impacts of what? Anthropogenic climate change exclusively? or climate variability at large? This are core questions in the definition of a rationale for adaptation funding. If adapting means addressing vulnerabilities, how can be distinguished between those climatic stimuli and other socioenvironmental factors defining those vulnerabilities. And even more: in what way is it adapting to those impacts different from development actions that address some of the most important factors of vulnerability: poverty and lack of governance capacity. Is the question of adaptation intrinsically tied to the problem of development in poor and emerging countries, and to questions of infrastructure, land use and urban planning in more developed countries?

Is adaptation funding the perpetuation of development funding with a different label? How is vulnerability taken into account in defining criteria for allocating the funds?

Current debates on adaptation reflect this transversal and multifaceted character of adaptation. How can adaptation be thought of and hence realized?

For example, agains very narrow framings of adaptation, some actors emphasize the condition of vulnerability and the importance of understanding its underlying causes and placing adaptation to climate change within a broader social, economic and environmental conception of vulnerability. Others identify climate change adaptation, particularly as including climate variability, as an extension of Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR), which can draw on a well-established community of practice (Mercer, 2010). And still others see adaptation as a path toward the making of a more resilient society, which involves less emphasis on the structural causes of vulnerability, but more on investment practices that produce and enhance resilience, and ultimately “good governance” (Adger and Brown, 2009; Adger et al., 2003). Moreover, the framings of adaptation seem to take specific forms in different development contexts (Huq and Reid, 2004).

The adaptation injunction thus has the potential of either reinforcing well established dynamics or to the contrary, reconfiguring existing domains of public and private

action.

Maps relevant to this questions are the following ones:

11. Geographical maps of Germany comparing projects in different sectors with vulnerability in the same sector

  • Projet: Amsterdam group 1
  • Current version: https://wiki.digitalmethods.net/Dmi/EmapsAmsterdamSprint2014Project1ClimateChangeStudiesOnAdaptationStrategiesInGermanyAndCentralEuropeMappingWithKompassDatabase 
  • Datasets: Kompass dataset
  • Improvements: all maps might be gathered in one interactive map
  • Findings: yes (there is little correlation between projects and vulnerability)

12. Scatterplots of countries comparing different multilateral adaptation funding compared to different vulnerability index

  • Projet: Amsterdam group 4 / Anders / Peter
  • Current version: https://wiki.digitalmethods.net/Dmi/EmapsAmsterdamSprint2014Project4UsesAndUsersOfVulnerabilityIndexes (project description page) https://docs.google.com/a/sciencespo.fr/file/d/0B4a4mDb99e7HaUdvM2hSaEZURm8/edit, https://docs.google.com/a/sciencespo.fr/file/d/0B4a4mDb99e7HV0E2Mm9ISWo2YVk/edit, https://drive.google.com/a/sciencespo.fr/?tab=mo#folders/0B0Qm7RJqWbEoVUJXQm5zaFdHZ2c
  • Datasets: Vulnerability indexes (Gain, Germanwatch, Dara, Human Development Index) and Climate Funds Update
  • Improvements:
  • Consider different ways of normalizing (https://docs.google.com/a/sciencespo.fr/file/d/0B4a4mDb99e7HNHdiLUl4UjcxY0k/edit)
  • the different maps can gathered in one interactive visualization
  • Findings: yes (strong correlation between development and adaptation)

13. Sankey diagram of bi-lateral funding (receiving countries ranked and colored by different vulnerability indexes)

  • Projet: Amsterdam group 4 / Anders / Peter
  • Current version: https://docs.google.com/a/sciencespo.fr/file/d/0B3DqwbcXRtUTWTE4am8tN3Y1Q00/edit 
  • Datasets: Vulnerability indexes (Gain, Germanwatch, Dara, Human Development Index) and OECD
  • Improvements:
  • compute the weighted average vulnerability for country groups (ex. Small Island States)
  • transform the continuous variable of vulnerability in a 5-class scale variable
  • group the countries that receive little amount of money in an ‘other’ category to remove the small streams from the viz

14. Bar-matrix of co-occurrence of themes and names of vulnerability indexes in the Web corpus

  • Projet: Amsterdam group 4 / Anders ou Mathieu
  • Current version: http://jiminy.medialab.sciences-po.fr/sprint_emaps_amsterdam/crosscount.php 
  • Datasets: Web corpus
  • Improvements:
  • see with Anders if the queries should be modified
  • add a tooltip to describe the acronyms of the queries
  • VIZ: embed the findings in the visualizations
  • Findings: yes (different indexes have different associational profile, see the presentation https://docs.google.com/a/sciencespo.fr/presentation/d/1pkfImE1wGwllOT090ydnJMPEnOL6y6v-fCUBnWn6HZ0/edit#slide=id.g129eb0f57_06)

15. Timeline showing mentions of vulnerability (and other) indexes in UNFCCC national communications

  • Projet: Amsterdam group 4 / Anders
  • Current version: https://docs.google.com/a/sciencespo.fr/presentation/d/1pkfImE1wGwllOT090ydnJMPEnOL6y6v-fCUBnWn6HZ0/edit#slide=id.g129eb0e7b_95 and https://docs.google.com/a/sciencespo.fr/presentation/d/1pkfImE1wGwllOT090ydnJMPEnOL6y6v-fCUBnWn6HZ0/edit#slide=id.g129eb0f57_22 
  • Datasets: UNFCCC national communications documents
  • Improvements:
  • Combine the two visualisation above
  • Possibly expand to other types of UNFCCC documents, although we have explored this possibility to some length without much success (there are few mentions of indexes in most types of documents from the UNFCCC + ENB reports)
  • Possibly expand to ENB corpus
  • Check if a solr index for the UNFCCC corpus exists and if it can be exploited for this viz (notably which tags are included in the index).
  • Check if a solr index for the ENB corpus exist and if it can be exploited for this viz (notably which tags are included in the index).
  • Try to understand why certain countries are interested in certain indexes (we have the data on which countries are citing each index in each year, although it does not show on the graph at the moment. See 16)
  • Findings: yes, the only index which seems to have some kind of wider traction in the UNFCCC process. This supports the hypothesis that the assessment of vulnerability to climate change is too controversial and uncertain and that therefore countries prefer to use development indicators as a baseline for funding decisions (developing countries need the money anyway)

17. Bipartites network of scientific journals citing different vulnerability and development indexes

  • Projet: Amsterdam group 4 / Anders
  • Current version: https://docs.google.com/a/sciencespo.fr/presentation/d/1pkfImE1wGwllOT090ydnJMPEnOL6y6v-fCUBnWn6HZ0/edit#slide=id.g129eb0e7b_028 
  • Datasets: Scientific papers citing indexes on Google Scholar
  • Improvements:
  • There is a problem with journals that are not really journals but databases (e.g. citeseer)
  • Findings: Yes, all the vulnerability indexes have very idiosyncratic audiences, i.e. they are being cited by each their group of journals with very few overlaps between them, suggesting that they are not being discussed against one another, but advanced by their proselytes. This is different with the big development indexes.

  1. 18 (there are other meta data than those the visualisation show, like time info, type of media , etc. -> visualization we chose will depend on the narrative). Pie chart of mentions of indexes in the media
  • Projet: Amsterdam group 4 / Anders
  • Current version: https://docs.google.com/a/sciencespo.fr/presentation/d/1pkfImE1wGwllOT090ydnJMPEnOL6y6v-fCUBnWn6HZ0/edit#slide=id.g129eb0f57_40 
  • Datasets: Lexis Nexis
  • Improvements:
  • We have a lot of metadata on types of media, time, country etc. This is the absolutely most basic chart we could make. More detailed charts can be made on the basis of the trans-map narratives
  • Maybe update the data by extracting them again from Lexis Nexis
  • Findings: Not yet

29.  Network of n-grams co-occuring in the paragraph of the ENB reports

  • Projet: Paris group 2 / Tommaso
  • Current version: https://drive.google.com/folderview?id=0B9mhIQ0fc0-8Vko2bjlQSmo0T2c&usp=sharing (Network_UNFCCCnegotiation_Language.png)
  • Datasets: ENB reports (http://www.iisd.ca/vol12/), simplified by keeping only the daily reports of the COPs and MOPs (https://drive.google.com/a/sciencespo.fr/folderview?id=0B_iWfy2O4wgATmh3UkhKak1qR0U&usp=sharing#)
  • Improvements:
  • If possible, develop an interactive version in which the verbatim of the occurence context of each n-gram is shown on click.
  • Tranform the HTML ‘indexed’ version of the corpus (http://62.210.188.24/negociations/web_cop_simpler2new.html) into a format that is more easy to query
  • In ‘indexed’ version the column "projection_cluster_ISItermscopindex_ISItermscopindex" contains both the name of the cluster and the name of the actual terms occuring in the paragraph. We would need to split this information in two columns.
  • Findings: Adaptation and mitigation have very different position in the network. Mitigation is present in many different thematic clusters that defines the structure of the network. Adaptation is concentrated in three (strongly connected) clusters that occupying the center of the network. Science and IPCC serve as a bridge among the different clusters.

30. Stream-graphs of the visibility of issues and countries in the ENB reports

  • Projet: Paris group 2
  • Current version: https://drive.google.com/folderview?id=0B9mhIQ0fc0-8Vko2bjlQSmo0T2c&usp=sharing (Streamgraph_UNFCCCnegotiaton.pdf)
  • Datasets:
  • ENB reports (http://www.iisd.ca/vol12/)
  • simplified by keeping only the daily reports of the COPs and MOPs (https://drive.google.com/a/sciencespo.fr/folderview?id=0B_iWfy2O4wgATmh3UkhKak1qR0U&usp=sharing#)
  • Table of countries occurence by COP https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B_iWfy2O4wgANDdlVlJyaWZYWXc/edit?usp=sharing
  • Table of topic occurence by COP https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B_iWfy2O4wgAblBJR0g4WF9TVFE/edit?usp=sharing 
  • Improvements:
  • Represent negotiation groups instead of single countries
  • Try to replace the stream-graph with a line-chart (the relative position of the streams is too sensible to little changes - a country/issue may move up a lot while increasing only a little their absolute visibility)
  • To reduce the visual cluttering, develop an interactive version in which different streams/lines can be visualized/hidden
  • Findings:
  • The funding of adaptation is a very visible topic of the negotiations from the beginning of the UNFCCC negotiations
  • Climate adaptation
